Stack
The stack is the memory set aside as scratch space for a thread of execution.
The stack is always reserved in a LIFO (last in first out) order; the most recently reserved block is always the next block to be freed.

item.description:
Cå¹¾å–å¹¾

Q1:
Ans: int Bin(int n, int m){ if(m == 0 || n == m)return 1; else return Bin(n - 1, m)+Bin(n-1, m-1); } è¤‡è£½
Q2:ä¾ä¸Šè¿°Codeæ±‚Bin(5, 3)å€¼å’Œå‘¼å«æ¬¡æ•¸ï¼š
Ans:
T(n, m) = T(n-1, m-1)+T(n-1, m)+1
T(1, 0) = 1
T(0, 0) = 1
Q3(æ¥µå°‘è€ƒ):Design Iterative or Dynamic programing æ±‚C(n, k)=?
Ans: int Bin(int n, int k){ int c[n+1][k+1]; for(int i = 0; i<= n; i++){ for(int j = 0; j<=min(i, k);j++){ if(j==0||j==i)c[i][j] = 1; else c[i][j]= c[i-1][j-1]+c[i-1][j]; } } return c[n][k]; } è¤‡è£½

code void Hanoi(int n, char A, char B, char C){ if(n == 1) printf("move disk %d from %c to %c \n", 1, A, C); else{ // move n-1 plate form A to B Hanoi(n-1, A, C, B); // move 1 plate form A to C Hanoi(1, A, B, C); // or printf("...") // move n-1 plate in B to C Hanoi(n-1, B, A, C); } } è¤‡è£½
